            I am currently a PhD candidate at the City University of New York in the Cognitive and Comparative Psychology program. I’m part of the Memory & Attention Lab with Dr. Timothy Ricker and the Memory and Metacognition Lab with Dr. Elizabeth Chua. My interests include working memory, long-term memory, and how these functions differ in various populations. I’m particularly interested in using behavioral methods, neuroimaging, and eye-tracking to answer questions about human cognition. I’m also interested in science communication.
            I graduated from the University of Rochester with a dual B.S./B.A. in Brain & Cognitive Sciences and Linguistics. Previously, I worked in the Division of Cognitive and Motor Aging at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine investigating computer-based cognitive remediation programs to improve cognition and mobility.
            You can reach me at kcotton@gradcenter.cuny.edu.

articles.title: Research
articles.description: How does information in working memory become information in long-term memory?
articles.contents:
My research focuses on the relationship between working memory and long-term memory, particularly how working memory processing can affect our long-term memory performance and other factors that influence this relationship.
What is the relationship between working memory consolidation and long-term memory?
This project looked at how manipulating working memory consolidation influences subsequent delayed recognition performance. Read more here.
This review also explores how working memory consolidation and long-term consolidation may be related.
What factors influence the effects of working memory processing on long-term memory?
This project explored how cognitive mechanisms supporting working memory consolidation are related to creativity and subsequent long-term retention. Read more here.
This ongoing project is exploring how mind-wandering impacts working memory performance, particularly across different experimental contexts.
The first part of this ongoing project explores how acute stress may impact the working memory processing.
